column1: 10:30|"half-past ten in the morning"|"Lying in the hot sun her mind was fixed upon the characters of her aunts

column7: “And

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"On and on she went
column2: by day and by night

column6: next scattered with white blocks which gradually separated themselves
column7: and then
column8: as the progress of the ship acted upon the view like a field-glass of increasing power
column9: became streets of houses. By nine o’clock the Euphrosyne had taken up her position in the middle of a great bay; she dropped her anchor; immediately
column10: as if she were a recumbent giant requiring examination
column11: small boats came swarming about her. She rang with cries; men jumped on to her; her deck was thumped by feet. The lonely little island was invaded from all quarters at once
column12: and after four weeks of silence it was bewildering to hear human speech. Mrs. Ambrose alone heeded none of this stir. She was pale with suspense while the boat with mail bags was making towards them. Absorbed in her letters she did not notice that she had left the Euphrosyne
column13: and felt no sadness when the ship lifted up her voice and bellowed thrice like a cow separated from its calf."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column2: their clothes suggesting late rising in untidy bedrooms

column7: turning all the light yellow. The clock now had a silent hall to tick in

column9: admitting a wedge of the hot summer day

column16: and ceasing. There was a pause. Then all those who had gone upstairs came down; cripples came

column18: holding the nurse’s finger; fat old men came still buttoning waistcoats. The gong had been sounded in the garden
column19: and by degrees recumbent figures rose and strolled in to eat
column20: since the time had come for them to feed again. There were pools and bars of shade in the garden even at midday
column21: where two or three visitors could lie working or talking at their ease."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: 12:00|midday|"Lunch went on methodically
column2: until each of the seven courses was left in fragments and the fruit was merely a toy
column3: to be peeled and sliced as a child destroys a daisy
column4: petal by petal. The food served as an extinguisher upon any faint flame of the human spirit that might survive the midday heat
column5: but Susan sat in her room afterwards
column6: turning over and over the delightful fact that Mr. Venning had come to her in the garden
column7: and had sat there quite half an hour while she read aloud to her aunt. Men and women sought different corners where they could lie unobserved
column8: and from two to four it might be said without exaggeration that the hotel was inhabited by bodies without souls. Disastrous would have been the result if a fire or a death had suddenly demanded something heroic of human nature
column9: but by a merciful dispensation
column10: tragedies come in the hungry hours. Towards four o’clock the human spirit again began to lick the body
column11: as a flame licks a black promontory of coal. Mrs. Paley felt it unseemly to open her toothless jaw so widely
column12: though there was no one near
column13: and Mrs. Elliot surveyed her round flushed face anxiously in the looking-glass."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

She was overcome with awe that things should exist at all.… She forgot that she had any fingers to raise.… The things that existed were so immense and so desolate.… She continued to be conscious of these vast masses of substance for a long stretch of time
column16: the clock still ticking in the midst of the universal silence."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"Whether too slight or too vague the ties that bind people casually meeting in a hotel at midnight
column2: they possess one advantage at least over the bonds which unite the elderly
column3: who have lived together once and so must live for ever. Slight they may be
column4: but vivid and genuine
column5: merely because the power to break them is within the grasp of each
column6: and there is no reason for continuance except a true desire that continue they shall. When two people have been married for years they seem to become unconscious of each other’s bodily presence so that they move as if alone
column7: speak aloud things which they do not expect to be answered
column8: and in general seem to experience all the comfort of solitude without its loneliness. The joint lives of Ridley and Helen had arrived at this stage of community
column9: and it was often necessary for one or the other to recall with an effort whether a thing had been said or only thought
column10: shared or dreamt in private. At four o’clock in the afternoon two or three days later Mrs. Ambrose was standing brushing her hair
column11: while her husband was in the dressing-room which opened out of her room
column13: through the cascade of water—he was washing his face—she caught exclamations
column14: “So it goes on year after year; I wish
column16: I wish I could make an end of it
column17: ” to which she paid no attention."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column3: and tended to hide itself from him. He was good-humoured towards them
column4: but contemptuous. She had always taken it for granted that his point of view was just
column5: and founded upon an ideal scale of things where the life of one person was absolutely more important than the life of another
column6: and that in that scale they were of much less importance than he was. But did she really believe that? Hewet’s words made her think. She always submitted to her father
column7: just as they did
column8: but it was her aunts who influenced her really; her aunts who built up the fine
column9: closely woven substance of their life at home. They were less splendid but more natural than her father was. All her rages had been against them; it was their world with its four meals
column11: and servants on the stairs at half-past ten
column12: that she examined so closely and wanted so vehemently to smash to atoms. Following these thoughts she looked up and said:"|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

She came in at half-past five and said that she had taken poison. They had only just time to get her into bed and call a doctor before she died."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column2: ” said Helen

column10: and then the forties. She realised that there is nothing to prevent nights from doing this if they choose. The sight had something inexplicably sinister about it
column11: and she was terrified and cried out
column12: upon which the woman laid down her cards and came across the room
column13: shading the candle with her hands. Coming nearer and nearer across the great space of the room
column14: she stood at last above Rachel’s head and said
column15: “Not asleep? Let me make you comfortable.”"|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: 12:00|midday|"After St. John had spent some hours in the heat of the sun wrangling with evasive and very garrulous natives
column2: he extracted the information that there was a doctor
column3: a French doctor
column4: who was at present away on a holiday in the hills. It was quite impossible
column5: so they said
column6: to find him. With his experience of the country
column7: St. John thought it unlikely that a telegram would either be sent or received; but having reduced the distance of the hill town
column8: in which he was staying
column9: from a hundred miles to thirty miles
column10: and having hired a carriage and horses
column11: he started at once to fetch the doctor himself. He succeeded in finding him
column12: and eventually forced the unwilling man to leave his young wife and return forthwith. They reached the villa at midday on Tuesday."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column10: as if she had been called out of her bed by a midnight alarm of fire
column13: her reserve and her composure; she talked to them quite familiarly as if she had nursed them and held them naked on her knee. She assured them over and over again that it was their duty to eat."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: ap < 11:00|"nearly eleven o’clock"|"It was nearly eleven o’clock when Dr. Lesage again appeared in the room. He approached them very slowly
column2: and did not speak at once. He looked first at St. John and then at Terence
column3: and said to Terence
column4: “Mr. Hewet
column5: I think you should go upstairs now.”"|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: ap ~ 09:30|"about half-past nine"|"At about half-past nine Miss Allan came very slowly into the hall
column2: and walked very slowly to the table where the morning papers were laid
column3: but she did not put out her hand to take one; she stood still
column4: thinking
column5: with her head a little sunk upon her shoulders. She looked curiously old
column6: and from the way in which she stood
column7: a little hunched together and very massive
column8: you could see what she would be like when she was really old
column9: how she would sit day after day in her chair looking placidly in front of her. Other people began to come into the room
column11: but she did not speak to any of them or even look at them
column13: as if it were necessary to do something
column14: she sat down in a chair
column15: and looked quietly and fixedly in front of her. She felt very old this morning
column17: as if her life had been a failure
column18: as if it had been hard and laborious to no purpose. She did not want to go on living
column19: and yet she knew that she would. She was so strong that she would live to be a very old woman. She would probably live to be eighty
column20: and as she was now fifty
column21: that left thirty years more for her to live. She turned her hands over and over in her lap and looked at them curiously; her old hands
column22: that had done so much work for her. There did not seem to be much point in it all; one went on
column23: of course one went on.… She looked up to see Mrs. Thornbury standing beside her
column24: with lines drawn upon her forehead
column25: and her lips parted as if she were about to ask a question."|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: ap ~ 03:00|"about three o’clock"|"“Yes
column2: ” she said. “She died this morning
column3: very early
column4: about three o’clock.”"|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"

column1: ap 03:30|"Half-past three"|"The block dissolved before Evelyn answered. But as she left them in the hall
column2: she looked at him brightly and said
column3: “Half-past three
column4: did you say? That’ll suit me.”"|"The Voyage Out"|"Virginia Woolf"
